Posts.Content: This was a healthy 80-year-old, not a high risk patient. It was good to read that the authors acknowledge we have increasingly healthy seniors in western society, and that care should be individualized, as was done here. Whatever goes for a healthy 80-year-old would favor even stronger arguments for a healthy 74-year-old, who per current guidelines would not be checked for PCA in the first place due to assumptions of lowered life expectancy based on age alone. . . . .Secondly, we think our 80-yr-old patient does have a life expectancy of more than 10 yr. According to the National Comprehensive Cancer Network guidelines, the life expec- tancy of octogenarians is 8.5 yr, but within the best quartile of agewhich can be assumed for our patient due to the lack of comorbiditiesit rises to 12.15 yr [1,7]. Concerns about undertreatment in healthy elderly men with high-risk pros- tate cancer have already been expressed by the Interna- tional Society of Geriatric Oncology. There have been several reports on otherwise healthy older patients with high-risk prostate cancer being less likely to receive local therapy in comparison to younger men with similar life expectancy [8]. This suggests that the life expectancy of healthy elderly men is commonly underestimated and emphasizes that individual health status rather than chronological age should guide treatment choices [9].

Posts.Content: 1. Another, which medication are you concerned about here as a cause of PSA drop? Do statins, blood thinners, and/or beta blockers which are what P. Collen is reporting as new, lower PSA and if so how much? With finasteride most double the measured PSA to correct for the lowering, but what is the data on the heart agents? 2. P. Collen, you just got a nice new stent and the blood thinner is there to help keep it from failing, most critical in the first few months after placement. How long did your cardiologist say you should be on it ( note they would need to be interrupted for the biopsy, and duration of using them can vary from one month to 18 months and averages a year). You also have raw irritable myocardial tissue as you are recovering from an MI, and most cardiologists, absent an emergency, do not recommend elective surgeries, even little ones like a biopsy, within 3 months of an MI, if not longer. That leads to the question if your PSA change is critical and pressing to work up more during the next couple months, stopping the thinners, risk/benefit assessment. Your PSA has not exactly surged, (unless your three cardiac drugs are known to lower it a lot) so perhaps you could ask your urologist and cardiologist what they might think about considering an in between approach, such as waiting 3 months, reassessing the PSA (no sex, masturbation, DRE, or heavy exercise 2-3 days before) and doing a prostate MRI (if your stent is the usual kind that does not interfere with MRI) in a facility that does a lot of them, and then only biopsy if there is a Pirads 4 or 5 lesion? Just a thought. I wish you a good recovery from your MI and a quiet prostate!

Posts.Title: Do I REALLY Need Another Biopsy

Posts.Content: The pre-bx rx we have waiting for pickup is for oral levoquin a couple hours before the biopsy, though he will be NPO for general anesthesia. It is a balance between risk of infection and even life-threatening sepsis and recurrent C. diff risk. We did tell the busy urologist about the C. diff hx when we established DH as new pt., ( he had gotten augmentin for tonsillectomy) but they just have their automatic protocol and it is unclear how to resolve the dilemma well. There are no controlled studies on healthy people getting prostate biopsies with and without a hx of C. diff from a simple prior surgery and prospectively either getting one antibiotic or another, and controlling for what the prior antibiotic was, and other C. diff risks.There are just general studies of all comers with and without antibiotics and sepsis rates, and the party line is you probably need antibiotics though unclear which one or how much. I talked to an infectious disease doc I know about this informally as I am not confident the urologist is thinking about it at all, and he said it is better to take chances on the C. diff than urosepsis. Sorry about the thread drift, and I know I am showing a bit of OCD about this whole process because I am aware from personal experience with health care so many things can go wrong behind the scenes, and am trying to save DH having to spend hours researching things himself, hours he does not have. He works 60 hours a week in a high stress job, I only work 45-50, though less lately due to medical appointments for him and for me. Djin, back on topic, I did find your nice genetic marker table, terrific, TU.

Posts.Title: Which specific cancer markers should one be sure and get on MRI-guided biopsy?

Posts.Content: DH is scheduled for MRI-guided bx of his 2.6x1.4 cm Pirads 4 lesion on 3/29 and I read in another thread that I should ask for genetic markers to be sent when the bx is done. I have been reading about genetic markers and it sounds like there are many choices and it is unclear if one has to do advance planning to get them other than asking. Putting aside cost and insurance coverage issues, are there particular markers I should ask for ahead of time, and if the doc and path forgets to send them, can one still ask for them after the bx is done? Communication in the busy urologist’s office is very difficult (no nurse manager, no email, all calls go to voicemail at a switchboard of clerks who may or may not return calls, or they route them to someone else’s voicemail, and the doctor, even though known for technical skill, has been too busy to listen or communicate well — did not call with MRI result until a week later, after we pursued it, and I now know it does not take that long to get results at that hospital).We have an appointment lined up for consultation with a new urologist 3/27 to plan ahead to likely do robotic surgery if needed based on bx results, as we need a place with better communication for the actual main surgery, but want to just go ahead with this scheduled biopsy as we have a date now, and we have already lost two months since the PSA was noted high. Around here things move slowly (e.g., a one month wait for a new pt appointment just for initial consult) unless you have pull and connections. The overworked and unhappy scheduling clerk gave me preop paperwork with usual instructions like stopping motrin and when to come etc., and said DH should also come in 3/28, just a day before surgery, to sign pre-bx consent and also fill out a list of boilerplate questions for the hospital. My sense is he may have just a few minutes with the doc then if any. Is there special preparation required for genetic markers? Will one day before surgery be too late to ask for genetic markers or oncotyping? I want to be ready to ask for specifically what I want sent as I suspect the doc will volunteer nothing and just have a “trust me we are in charge and I am too busy to talk more” manner.

BTW in these days of my cancer worries every time I see your user name as I read this forum I feel like pulling out a bottle of Hendricks, hold the tonic!

Posts.Content: ASAdvocate, I am just planning ahead for all likely contingencies. I am unfortunately aware of all the side effects that can occur with prostate surgery even in the best hands. He had a simple tonsillectomy with one course of antibiotics preop a few years ago and landed up with two months of debilitating. C. diff! I did not mention here before on this thread that DH has had sxs BPH for years before his PSA went up, but kept dodging going to a urologist because he is always super busy at work. But when he finally went with me to see this urologist with both the PSA rise , < 10 percent free, and the reported worsening BPH sxs, while we were waiting for the 4k to come back, the doc did flow studies documenting slow flow recently, and high residual volume, and then we also had misc findings of chronic obstruction on MRI. He then tried a couple different alpha blockers and could not tolerate the myriad of side effects even at low doses, so at some point he will almost certainly need some level of a prostate procedure, like surgery, anyway to control those sxs. He is only 57 and pretty healthy now except for odds and ends, and is a good general anesthesia candidate. He may be open to AS even for a life of potentially another 25 years, but as he also needs the BPH treated, it may be a two birds with one stone issue. If the MRI fusion bx is totally negative, unlikely with all we know, and awareness that there are some false negagives, we will of course have a lot more time to pick a good surgeon for benign prostate procedures. But if his PCA is high grade, I want to be ready, as everything moves so slow here and I understand doubling time can be as short as a few months. If it were not for his work, which keeps him so busy, I would just have him travel to the best prostate centers in the country for opinions, like Hopkins or Mayo, but he is unwilling to do that, wants to do things locally. I appreciate your words of caution, and understand of course one needs full analysis of the bx, by a good pathologist, and by reliable people who have enough time to think about things, (and probably also a second pathologist to look at the specimen, like they did with my breast cancer) before doing surgery. I had way less trouble in this area finding a skilled and communicative breast cancer surgeon (off my insurance plan) than I have been having setting up urology opinions for DH.

Posts.Content: I found this report from 2010 in my recent research file about surgical delays of six months or more creating more problems in Gleason 3+3 men, so if the results have been proven valid since then (not finished researching) I cannot see how results would be better for 3+4. “ AUA: Delayed Surgery Boosts Prostate Cancer Risk Charles Bankhead,May 31, 2010 Action Points SAN FRANCISCO -- Men with low-risk prostate cancer had significantly worse outcomes if they delayed surgery for six months or more after their diagnosis, data from a large retrospective cohort showed. The study looked at the medical records of more than 1,100 men with low-risk prostate cancer and found that those who delayed surgery had almost double the likelihood of having high-grade disease at prostatectomy; twice as many men had biochemical progression compared with patients who had surgery less than six months after diagnosis. "In a contemporary prospective radical prostatectomy cohort of low-risk prostate cancer patients, we found that a delay in surgery of six months or more after diagnosis was associated with worse outcomes, specifically, a significantly greater proportion of high-grade disease and higher rates of biochemical progression," Gustavo F. Carvalhal, MD, of Northwestern University in Chicago, said here at the American Urological Association meeting. "Low-risk patients should be counseled about the possibility of worse pathological outcomes and an increased risk of biochemical progression with surgical delays of six months or more," Carvalhal added. "Further studies are necessary to ascertain whether these findings will translate into a difference in cancer-specific and overall mortality rate." As more men opt for active surveillance of low-risk prostate cancer, timing of surgery has emerged as a key consideration during follow-up. Studies of surgical delay's impact on outcomes have yielded conflicting results. One of the earliest studies showed that a delay of three months or more from diagnosis was associated with a lower 10-year biochemical progression-free survival (Can J Urol 2003; 10: 1891-199. Several subsequent studies showed similar outcomes regardless of the interval between biopsy and surgery, said Carvalhal. Still another study showed an increased risk of biochemical relapse in men who delayed surgery for more than six monhs after a positive biopsy (J Urol 2006; 175: 1298-1302). In light of the inconsistent findings, Carvalhal and colleagues assessed the impact of surgical delay on biochemical progression in a contemporary series of patients with low-risk prostate cancer. They analyzed data on 1,111 men who underwent retropubic radical prostatectomy. All met D'Amico criteria for low risk: clinical stage T1c/T2a, PSA ≤10 ng/mL, and biopsy Gleason score ≤6. Defining biochemical recurrence as a postprostatectomy rise in serum PSA to ≥0.2 ng/mL, investigators compared pathologic features and biochemical recurrence rates in men who had surgery within six months of diagnosis or after six months. Of the total cohort, 59 patients had surgery six months or more after diagnosis, and the remaining 1,052 underwent prostatectomy within six months. Longer surgical delay was associated with older age (61 versus 59, P=0.05), African-American race (6.8% versus 2.2%, P=0.05), and a lower proportion of clinical stage T2 versus T1 disease (6.8% versus 18.9%, P=0.02). At prostatectomy the percentage of patients in the two groups did not differ significantly with respect to organ-confined disease, extracapsular extension, positive surgical margins, or seminal vesicle invasion, and no patient in either group had lymph node involvement. However, 47% of patients who delayed surgery for six months or longer had Gleason ≥7 compared with 27% of men who had less delay from diagnosis to surgery (P=0.001). Both groups had a median follow-up of about 40 months. Biochemical recurrence occurred in 5% of patients who had surgery within six months of diagnosis versus 12% in the men who waited six months or longer (P=0.04). A surgical delay of six months or more was associated with a five-year progression-free survival of about 80% compared with about 95% in men who did not delay surgery (P=0.0086). In a multivariable analysis a surgical delay of six months or more remained a significant predictor of biochemical progression, conferring almost a threefold increase in the hazard (HR 2.9, P=0.02). Carvalhal reported no disclosures. Reviewed by Zalman S. Agus, MD Emeritus Professor University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine and Dorothy Caputo, MA, RN, BC-ADM, CDE, Nurse Planner”

AgeInfo.Phrase: was associated with older age  61 versus 59  P=0 05   African
with older age  61 versus 59  P=0 05   African American race

Posts.Title: Should we delay the surgery?

Posts.Content: A second opinion by a reputable, preferably academic PCA center , including perhaps a radiation therapy consult, may be in order for your 69-year-old dad, depending on his other health issues , overall risks of surgery, surgical delay if he gets stented, and other health issues. You mentioned that your dad had declined cardiac cath before because he felt fine. Presumably the cardiologist had explained to him that men can feel fine but have a significant coronary lesion, like a left main coronary or three vessel obstruction, where the first symptoms would be sudden death and not just feeling poorly, but he still declined. So query how he would feel about surgical risks vs benefits of a prostatectomy in the presence of CAD, vs. alternatives such as XRT, or other options already mentioned. Certainly many men underestimate cardiac risks and prefer to leave well enough alone if they feel fine, but worry more about cancer and want something done, want it out, whether justified or not. Be also careful about assuming that the request for “clearance” means the docs are really talking properly to each other, and that you and your dad really understand risks and pros and cons and unknowns. Many surgeons just want a CYA for anyone with heart disease getting major surgery, and there is often no more than electronic record stamping after “clearance” (not saying this is the case with your dad, just be cautious, as seniors with heart disease, stented or not, do die or have complications from anesthesia, emboli, bleeding and post-op infections).

AgeInfo.Phrase: be in order for your 69 year old dad  depending on

Posts.Title: Should we delay the surgery?

Posts.Content: Mama, you are going through the same thoughts I had when my DH first had a PSA rise with low free PSA, i.e., “it must be BPH” though I worried it was likely not, and then when there was a big PiRads 4 peripheral lesion on MRI that “it could still be a false positive.” During that hunt for still having hope, while waiting for the bx, I found this article about false positives in the peripheral zone (where most PCA arises), and there are indeed quite a few, as others mentioned: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/301288625_Benign_causes_of_diffusion_restriction_f oci_in_the_peripheral_zone_of_the_prostate_diagnos is_and_differential_diagnosis There are many potential false positives, but the bx is the gold standard, and combined with clinical hx, PSA rate of rise, free PSA, and other clinical factors I have tried to get myself used to the idea DH has PCA and just hope it is not bad. Bx with MRI guidance, fusion, was 3/29 on DH, still no results. Our friend had a blind TRUS bx the same day with another center and another doc and he got results yesterday. Tomorrow I start calling to make sure the busy doc complex is not just sitting on a report that was already read out and they have been too preocuppied to call us about. Would be nice to have a good weekend
Posts.Title: MRI results and a ?

Posts.Content: Lay overview of PiRads scoring system, old and new versions. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/PI-RADS Pirads 4 is high probablity of significant malignancy (5 would be very high probability). But take heart, because as discussed above, it could be a false positive. DH was not hearing anything from his overloaded doc about his 3/29 MRI guided and US fusion bx of his 2.6x1.4 cm PiRads lesion in the peripheral zone, so yesterday I just went over to get the report from the hospital directly (he signed a form for them indicating I could) .The 12 “standard template” cores were all read as benign prostate tissue, and the four taken from the area of suspicion were read as benign prostate tissue and seminal vesicle. It was signed “ pathology staff” so I cannot check how versed the pathologist is in reading prostate tissue. But before I change my username, though this is good news, I want to look into the possibility of a false negative. The doc finally called DH (who also has very symptomatic BPH and a 50 gram or double size prostate on MRI) and quickly said “Your biopsies were benign. See you in 6 months.” He was getting ready to hang up but DH quickly asked what about a false negative , given the big Pirads 4 lesion, and the doc reluctantly replied “well that can happen”. He then tried to hang up again and DH asked what he should do about the BPH (e.g., thinking if he has surgery as an option we would get another crack at tissue to help rule out false negative). The doc was surprised, and said “oh, you still have that?”, and then told him to schedule a cystoscopy and hung up. Apparently he was not spending much time with DH’s record, and no reason was given for the cystoscopy after-thought (we already know his prostate size, he has no blood in urine, no incontinence, and no neuro disease), and to do it late May because he is on vacation until then. I also saw on the report I picked up that the results were available less than 24 hours after the bx, Friday, so we could have had a more peaceful weekend if the doc had bothered to look and let us know! He also took eight days to notify us of MRI results, most get it in two. We will not be going back there and will follow up with a new urologist we met shortly before the bx who spent a lot of time discussing. Key points: 1. There can be false positives as discussed above in prior posts, but also false negatives, as PCA is diffuse, though I hope DH is not in the latter category (PSA around 4 with under 10 percent free, a big jump from last few years when he was in the 1’s, and positive family history.). If DH has to have most or all of the prostate out for bad BPH anyway, we will know for sure. 2. Patients need to be on the ball about what is happening with them, “trust but verify” when dealing with docs, they are busy, and to many, you are just another John Doe. Most who are not salaried get payed in bulk, e.g., for how many procedures they do and bill for, rather than how much time they spend explaining things to pts.

AgeInfo.Phrase: overloaded doc about his 3 29 MRI guided and US fusion

Posts.Title: MRI results and a ?

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear about your dad, Devorie. In addition to the other questions others asked, does your dad have other health problems, even if he is still working? Even if it has not spread, docs may opt for radiation with PCA instead of surgery if a patient is high risk for prolonged general anesthesia, infection or recovery ( lung, heart, diabetes, problems, even weird shape of throat for hard intubation are just a few examples) and as already asked, age.

Posts.Title: nervously waiting for surgery

Posts.Content: My DH, age 57, pretty healthy, working, and active, has not yet been diagnosed with PCA (and hopefully never will be). As some of you may recall from my other posts, he had first round MRI fusion biopsies recenty read as benign, including four cores reportedly targeted to his PiRads 4 2.6x1.4 cm left peripheral lesion. I am in the process of getting second opinions on the path and MRI reads, because of various reasons for clinical suspicion of PCA including the big Pirads 4 lesion, which will take a while. DH so far is not keen on starting over and getting more biopsies of that lesion at a major PCA center to increase odds of finding hidden PCA , but would like to get going on rx of his annoying but not debilitating BPH sxs in summer. He would be willing to read about reasons to wait a bit longer for BPH rx rather than just doing BPH rx with TURP or GreenLight laser or perhaps Urolift (more temporary) this summer and then just continuing PSA and DRE monitoring for PCA every few months after a recovery period, and worry about occult PCA later, which is what the two urologists suggest. So I am researching what kind of problems you can get with finding PCA and doing prostatectomy a year or more in the future if he were to get limited BPH surgery now. Prostate is only twice normal, 50 grams, so he would not be a candidate for a prostatectomy for the BPH now, which would give a lot of tissue, and TURP would only give tissue near the urethra, not where the lesion is, Greenlight would give none or only a little if a loop is added for some. PSA was 4.2, confirmed, after years of running in the 1’s, < 10% free, FH PCA but no deaths from it. My understanding is scarring from TURP at least can make nerve sparing prostatectomy later on, if needed for PCA, harder to do. Unclear what Greenlight does. Is that correct, and are there other risks, or good papers on this? Anyone here had a TURP or Greenlight in the past and then have prostatectomy for PCA? If yes, did your doc talk about greater risk of problems due to prior BPH surgery? As DH is young and has some IBS, he would not be keen on radiation, if PCA found in the future, both due to young age, and risk of GI SE, as well as SE that would interfere with the very high level of cognitive function he needs for his job, even if it were for just a few months ( says it would be better to wear incontinence pads than to have no energy and not be able to think clearly for months)

Posts.Title: Any good review articles on problems with PCA surgery/rx after earlier BPH surgeries?

Posts.Content: The average PSA bump after T replacement into a therapeutic range, with a normal prostate, has been reported to be 0.3-0.6. However, if testosterone is supratherapeutic, what is expected is not standardized. If clomid is added on, (not routine) even less so. Men with BPH bump their PSAs a bit higher, but so can men with cancer. Indeed, some urologists see a signifcant PSA bump with T to be a stress test for underlying prostate disease, both benign and malignant, but research on this is murky. Even if you got in with a urologist immediately, odds are he would just tell you to knock it off with the T and the clomid and repeat the PSA in 4-6 weeks (and, as others have noted, avoid things that can cause false positives). When you do the repeat, perhaps you should ask for both a total and free PSA ( very low free PSA can mean increased risk of PCA, but there are false positives). A urologist is not going to be swayed one way or the other by your estrogen levels. Are you obese? Do you have a family history of PCA? Are you African-American? All could increase risk of PCA. June is a perfect time for a urology appointment, as that is when PSA should settle down after stopping the T and clomid.
Posts.Title: TRT and PSA Jump

Posts.Content: Zaldamo, I am sorry to hear about your stepdad. May I ask how old he is, and how close your relationship is? Are you pretty much the main family member for him, e.g., no wife, no other kids? How was his emotional health before the diagnosis? Does he *want* your help? As others have said, and you suspect, from a pure medical perspective, he should be in the care of a urologist and urologic oncologist who has a lot of experience with metastatic prostate cancer. A regular community guy can certainly do fine, and it sounds like he is set up for likely hormone blockers which is also likely appropriate, but if your step-dad wants your help to get the best overall care possible (including pain relief) I would encourage getting a second opinion from your local university center hospital, at a minimum. Alternatively, if he is a vet and eligible for VA care based on income or service-connection, he can go to the Cincinnati VA ( most VAs have a lot of experience with PCA because of Agent Orange and, contrary to TV news, if they are affiliated with a local university hospital, they can do a very good job taking care of vets with PCA at either low or no cost). If he has a good relationship with his primary care doc, that doc can also steer you to good local options. He, and you, if you have been close, will almost certainly also need emotional care, to help cope with the new diagnosis, and especially if he had preexisting depression or anxiety. I looked online and there are a variety of local prostate cancer support services in the Cincinnati area for patients and family that meet regularly, no cost (I am not sure if I am allowed to mention them here, so no link), to complement medical workup. VA also offers psychology services, if he is a vet. Give him a little space, and then ask him how you can best help him, if it would be ok to have your involvement, and maybe ask if it would be ok if you went to his next appointment with him (if you can do that). He may have already heard from his doc that the likely ADT hormone shots he is set up for will block sexual function, among other major side effects, and along with pain and having cancer, thinking about that can make men angry and cranky or depressed, plus they feel they are losing control, losing their manliness ( certainly they lose their male hormone). Offer to help, and be there if he wants it, on his terms, so he is engaged in his care while you nudge him in the best direction for him, with his unique situation and values. People are also here to help you as best possible. Best wishes on his care.

Posts.Title: Help for Newly Diagnosed D2 Prostate Cancer with Bone Mets

Posts.Content: Are you seeing someone in the best prostate cancer you can access, even if it means traveling somewhere? A university center, perhaps? Everyone is different with how their body copes with disease, even metastatic disease, in how long they go on, which is why docs hate to be cornered into saying how long someone will live. Just try and get expedited second and third opinions if you can and see if there is anything else to try. If not, at least secure adequate pain relief and enjoy while you can. Gentle hugs and hope, PCASpouse. I am so sorry, but where there is life there is hope, many of us have seen amazing things. I hope my DH will not be there in the future and am doing my darndest to avoid it.

Posts.Title: Prostate MRI Results

Posts.Content: 1. Another, viagra (sildenafil) and cialis (tadalafil) are both in the drug class of PDE5 inhibitors, which improve penile blood flow when stimulation is given. Neither can be taken by men on nitrates, due to potential life-threatening BP drop. They do have differences in duration of action and a few other things, as shown in the charts here, even though they are in the same class of drugs: http://www.price-rx.com/sexual.shtml 2. Tincture of time can certainly improve erections, plus all the usual about healthy diet and exercize, but as you know, at least some reputable urologists advocate penile rehabilitation early after surgery, to avoid a “use it or lose it” phenomenon. More research is needed. https://www.harvardprostateknowledge.org/new-options-for-treating-erectile-dysfunction It would be good to know how to detect patients in advance, such as yourself, who will have a bad reaction to injections. Right now the only patients noted to be more likely to have problems such as prolonged priapism are those with sickle trait, those also taking trazodone or buproprion, and those who had priapism before. Some urologists just recommend pure alprostadil, i.e., not a “mix”, e.g., Edex, Caverject, or vacuum pumps, e.g., Erecaid, which are harmless enough though seem awkward. Most Erecaid success seems to be with married couples who incorporate the pump into a foreplay game, i.e., make the Erecaid a sex toy, rather than an unwanted foreign object. People who have horrible headaches, stuffy nose, and reflux with viagra and cialis are then stuck with injections or a pump for penile rehab options. Djintonic, should this thread be moved to the ED section?
Posts.Title: 4 months post surgery - update

Posts.Content: Well, at least after the MRI fusion bx 3/29, (I drove him home) he had no pain when he rode a MC a few miles to and from work on 4/3, and no bleeding. He took a car to work on 3/30 just in case. I will update further on sequelae when/if he gets a prostatectomy, for future riders doing research.
Posts.Title: Experiences of motorcyclists who have had prostate surgery?

Posts.Content: At night, some patients with catheters they are not used to are so uncomfortable they just need to knock themselves out to sleep, e.g., with zolpidem (Ambien) Also take a close look near the meatus and make sure there is no erosion or tearing that could be causing out of ordinary pain

Posts.Title: 4 months post surgery - update

Posts.Content: I posted elsewhere about my DH, who is getting a bx tomorrow for a large Pirads 4 lesion that is likely PCA. DH is an avid motorcyclist, e.g., he not uncommonly rides on and off road the whole day, and routinely also a short distance to work so parking is easy and efficient. I have researched the internet on experiences of motorcyclists as well as medical center instructions after both bx and prostatectomy and there is very little out there. There is a lot more about regular bicycling. Some say there should be no riding for two weeks after bx and one month after surgery, to allow healing, even if it feels ok, others reported they did not feel comfortable riding more than a few miles until many months had passed after surgery and for healing you need two months even if the butt feels ok. His seat is pretty soft on his main bike, but roads, except to work, can be bumpy. DH will of course do what it takes to get proper rx once the path comes back, as there are no awesome rides to experience if you are dead. But we are trying to plan ahead for both work transportation as well as whether or not to pay fees in advance for some bigger organized rides out of the area. If he has surgery, it will likely be mid to late June ( subject to path findings, of course). If anyone who rides who had bx and surgery has anything to add to this, it would be appreciated!

Posts.Title: 2 days post op

Posts.Content: I went to personally pick up the 3 Tesla MRI report. The scheduling woman said earliest bx opportunity is 3/29 late afternoon, so we took it. I asked for a copy of the DVD with the images, so I have them to take to another urologist (planning ahead) and after she first said that was “not possible” and I corrected her and insisted that it is, I left fifteen min later with the DVD Impression: PiRADS oversll score IV, left peripheral zone mid gland to base diffuse asymmetric hypointense lesion on T 2 sequences with mild diffusion and perfusion asymmetry.” Recommendation: Artemis fusion biopsy which is scheduled. I will ask for genetic markers too I am not sure why this is not PIRADS 5 given the maximum length is 2.6 and 4 level is supposed to be less than 1.5 cm in greatest dimension. “there is a large zone of moderately mild asymmetric T2 hypointensity diffusion signal abnormality seen within the left peripheral zone of the prostate mid gland to base visualized on image 24 measuring up to 2.6 x 1.4 cm . . . .”
Posts.Title: What is the specificity (false negative?) on prostate MRI?

Posts.Content: Thank you for the welcome! Communal answers: My husband is 57. <10% of his PSA (confirmed on repeat) was free, suggestive but not confirmatory of CA. He first saw a urologist mid-January after we got the results from primary care. We were in pursuit of getting a biopsy when we noted the PSA had gone up from years of a steady baseline, with the low free PSA, but he reported also having BPH sxs (negative DRE) on the review of systems. Then the urologist got fixated on giving him an alpha blocker trial to treat that (not tolerated), doing urinary flow and residual studies for BPH work-up (not surprisingly he had slow flow and some retention was confirmed) and giving him brochures about the different surgical ways to rx BPH since he did not tolerate pills.. Meanwhile getting the bx was held up by waiting for the 4K lab the doc recommended. When it came back two weeks later it frankly did not add much to the free PSA, and reported 15% risk of a significant lesion, which we already knew from the free PSA lab report, so the plan was finally to do the biopsy, which we wanted in the first place. We thought he was then finally going for an MRI-guided biopsy last week but due to massive, pan-miscommunication it turned out to be only the MRI. He/I had taken a full day off anticipating biopsy with sedation. He had called his doc's office as well as insurance in advance about his "MRI-guided biopsy" and was told the procedure was covered, but it turned out they only did the MRI and no one knew anything about a biopsy. We now have our MRI result reported verbally by the urologist yesterday (it is like pulling teeth in this ACO bureaucracy to get a copy of the actual report, but I am submitting a ROI request for the report and films). Now the battle starts to contact the clerk girls to schedule the actual MRI-guided biopsy and make sure they schedule the right thing. Doc told DH they are going to use general anesthesia to avoid his moving around. We will confirm coverage amount in that hospital, where they like to overcharge paying patients so as to be able to pay for people who have no coverage, so we have to be clear going on what the charges will be that are covered by insurance and if the remainder is an acceptable amount. Doc told DH the lesion (no details) is in an area that would have been biopsied anyway even without MRI guidance (but was not felt on DRE). I assume they will take extra samples of that area, if we could just get it done! We are in northern California, Bay area, and he has United Health Care, but we would be willing to pay a reasonable amount extra if it were not covered. MRI guided bx is, as I understand it, state of the art for guidance on bx, so maybe that is why it is covered now. I am not sure if that also requires combination with ultrasound. I have been reading, trying to learn. Meanwhile as I have little confidence in this confused personnel ACO complex, though we will stick with them for the biopsy to keep things moving (surgeon has a good reputation as a surgeon, but I am unimpressed with his staff and the complex), I am working to line up a new urologist both for a second opinion on what procedure would be best to do after the biopsy (assuming it will be positive), and perhaps to actually also do it even if it means traveling further from our home. My husband rides motorcycles on long trips and likes to take cars on race tracks as a hobby (not for a long time before doing the PSA blood, BTW, so his results are not a false + ). So if surgery is required for a bad cancer, the last thing he needs is landing up with urinary incontinence (not that any man needs that). We want to minimize chances of a poor result due to a rushed and overworked surgeon and confused personnel. This PCA work-up is coming on top of my getting a surprise breast cancer diagnosis 4 months ago (am doing ok), and I'll also toss in putting our favorite cat to sleep last month due to a one-inch abdominal tumor, so I am stressed. Oddly, he is not feeling stressed, maybe it will hit the way it hit me when the biopsy comes back positive (hopefully not, but looking likely).

Posts.Title: What is the specificity (false negative?) on prostate MRI?

Posts.Content: Brendi, I am so sorry you have to be here to try and help DH. If the PCA is truly not gone, there are still options, Lay over view of some of them: https://www.webmd.com/prostate-cancer/prostate-cancer-faq#1 Where you are geographically? I would suggest getting a new opinion by a prostate cancer center of excellence near you, e.g., at the local university is always a start, though best known are Hopkins, MD Anderson, UCLA, Stanford, Duke, Vanderbilt, there are a couple in NY and Chicago, and of course Mayo Clinic. I would gather all his records copies to yourself to be ready to hand carry to his appointment so they do not get lost, and get a fresh look. His doc may be doing all he can do that is appropriate, but new sets of eyes can be helpful. Djintonic also has an extensive research file, and take a look at the stickies. I wish you and your DH the best, as my DH and I wait for results of a biopsy of a suspicious prostate lesion.
Posts.Title: Prostate cancer after treatments

Posts.Content: Most of the younger doctors have been trained NOT to do DRE in asymptomatic men for PCA screening, but only to do them for other reasons. Plus, given tremendous false positive and false negatives on DRE, (compared with less on assessing PSA velocity, vs isolated PSAs) and also the anti-PCA screening mania until very recently, it is not surprising that they have fallen by the wayside. But as others have said, with your present PSA, odds are miniscule that you have PCA now. But, you now have a nice baseline so you can monitor your velocity. If cost is no great concern, however, having a urologist on standby with the same finger and same lab each year, is a good idea with your family history, as younger and newer primary care docs have other things on their minds to worry about and concerns about your prostate may get diluted. BTW per this article, which also explains why DRE is mostly out for PCA screening and is still in for other problems, half of the kiddies graduating from medical training in Canada have never done a DRE, much less a bunch of them. http://www.cbc.ca/news/health/prosta...exam-1.4570631

Posts.Content: Longer fingers on a doctor, regardless of sex, could be handy if a patient is very obese, because there is more flesh to go past to be able to reach into the key area and still get to the prostate. Most women prefer female gyncologists, so I understand if some men prefer male urologists. Other men actually report they prefer a woman doing DRE, (if anyone), and talking to women docs rather than men about sexual dysfunction, as there are less potential negative associations, and think there may be less judgment. I once had the pleasure of meeting a woman urologist when there were less than a dozen board-certified in the whole country. She was tall and athletic and had long fingers, perhaps coincidence . And her dad was a urologist, which is how she got interested, and how she got the residency position in a day when it was so rare ( that and bring brilliant). She is now quite famous for her own academic work and surgeries.

Posts.Content: ADT leads to testosterone deprivation, and there is a wide body of imperfect literature that has shown low T can in some cases lead to insulin resistance and glucose rises. However, trials of giving T in non PCA pts did not improve glucose control. Have you also gained weight or exercized less since ADT, which is common? That could lead to high glu and insulin resistance too. Let your GU know, but also your internist today about the glus, so you can start on appropriate DM regimen including diet, exercise, meds, Hba1c monitoring. I have seen people on ADT who started it while diabetic so it is not likely to interfere if it gets controlled. BTW hopefully you also have a baseline BMD or a plan to protect your bone with your internist ( and if he knows nothing about it, seek out an endocrinoloogist). After a couple years of ADT, BMD t scores went down -1.8 in a study and can push you into osteoporosis. Diabetics are already at independent risk of osteoporosis too.
Posts.Title: Diabetes Complication?

Posts.Content: This was a big multicenter trial, randomized, and included European centers, results favor doing MRI before bx (which most people here already know) and not doing bx if negative, just published online 3/19/18 in NEJM Even though MRI is favored (men who did not have a significant lesion on MRI did not get a bx), net balancing of costs and insurance coverage (e.g., U.S.) are not well addressed, and the discussion section has criticisms. http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1801993
Posts.Title: NEJM new paper favors MRI guided bx as standard of care

Posts.Content: Hello again, Jess! I believe your DH’s bx was two-three weeks ago? My DH had one 3/29. He had a little bit of butt pain with prolonged sitting or with squatting starting three days after bx, not testicular pain, and almost nothing now. He had some pink urine from blood for a couple days and bloody ejaculate for a week, all cleared now, we had been warned about that. His urologist told him it takes about 4-8 weeks for healing, sometimes longer ( that is why they wait at least a month before doing prostatectomy, though data is a bit iffy on whether that is important). If an MRI is done too soon after a bx it may cause false positive spots from pooled traumatized tissue. Our understanding from him is that after the intial post-bx period of taking it easy and not doing heavy exertion, regular exercize is ok but listen to the body, and does not necessarily accelerate healing. There is no diet or supplement our docs recommended to accelerate healing, just eat healthy and go easy on alcohol. If your DH has a lot of testicular pain several weeks after bx he should probably see his urologist. An infection can occur after bx and can radiate into testes though usually there is also burning with urination. Sorry he is having trouble — call your care team about the symptoms.

Posts.Content: As I posted elsewhere, DH at age 57 (otherwise pretty healthy) had a confirmed PSA bump from the 1’s over several years, to sudden 3.8-4.3, <10% free, confirmed twice under proper circumstances, and due to FH of PCA in dad and a Pirads4 lesion with a 2.6x1.4 cm left peripheral lesion on MRI, he had a fusion bx. He never had any prior biopsies but he has had BPH sxs building up over several years. Prostate is 50gm on MRI and US. 12 standard template cores came back benign prostate tissue. Four cores from the targeted area came back benign prostate tissue and seminal vesicle. These were signed off on by a pathologist who is around 50 (unclear where she did residency) and is on staff in a major SF Bay area community hospital. Urologist is now offering BPH procedures like TURP or Greenlight laser and did not recommend repeat bx. TURP would give us more tissue but not from where the MRI abnormality is, Greenlight would not unless they added a loop which would give a little. DH is not keen on PAE at one of the places that does it which also would not give tissue. I am happy biopsies were negative, but understand there can still be false negatives on MRI bx, so still worry about missing PCA given the whole story as I also understand there can be false positives on MRI. I also understand if you do TURP it can later interfere with PCA surgery if PCA is found later. I am sending the slides to Epstein’s lab at Hopkins for a second opinion for a fee, cash pay (they published that 6 % of second opinion slides they get were originally read as totally benign, so I am not the only worry wart). I would also like to get a second opinion on the MRI, thinking perhaps it was overread, but cannot find anywhere online to send it in. Anyone know of reputable online prostate MRI readers? DH is too busy to travel elsewhere out of the Bay area for a face to face appointment like at Mayo where they would reread the MRI, which would be another way to get another MRI read, so I am limited to online rereviews. If Epstein confirms biopsies are negative and an experienced PCA MRI reader says there is nothing much there, I will relax a bit more.

Posts.Title: Is there a reputable on line prostate MRI second opinion site?

Posts.Content: Here are the different organization recommendations for “screening”. My preference is that of the American Cancer Society, which adjusts based on risk and life expectancy. https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-...-20048087?pg=2 Note also that “screening” only refers to checking when there are no clinical signs or symptoms. Docs should still check PSA to work up patients with symptoms, e.g., urinary or bone symptoms that are not clearly explained, or who have unexplained weight loss. Many have forgotten that, in the prior USPSTF created furor of the last few years, (when not screening anyone, not even high risk patients, was the norm, until 2017 when recommendations were changed), many organizationally salaried docs had fear of checking PSA at all. In my area docs treating vets are still not reminded on the computer to screen for PCA in appropriately aged or risk patients, though they are reminded about 40 or so other things, like looking for falls, colon cancer of course, homelessness, PTSD, smoking and “food insecurity”.
Posts.Title: Looks like old guys over 70 do not have to worry about death from PC

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DavefromMD The article does state that one of reasons for these results in VA is cost control. There's almost always $$$ involved in some way one way or another. I was very fortunate in that my doctors emphasized they get paid the same no matter what treatment I choose as they were all on salary and not paid by the procedure. One thing all these studies do not take into account is personal preference . . . “ . Dave, you may feel “fortunate” that VA doctors (and two-thirds of other doctors now, since the passage of ACA, previously only one-third) are salaried and get paid the same no matter what they do, but this cuts both ways. PCA screening is more work for salaried primary care docs, and then more work for urologists. Then it is more work for salaried urologists to do biopsies. The incentives for salaried docs, whether conscious or not, is to do less, but still get the same salary, just like some fee for service docs have incentive to do more for more income. Docs doing less can always point to gray area studies favoring their doing less. And government often has incentive to get away with cutting corners to avoid what may be considered bloated budgets. [Loeb] “suggested that one reason VA may be adhering to national guidelines at a higher rate is its lack of financial incentives for salaried physicians to recommend expensive fee-for-service procedures. “ At least at our local VA, (in the top two in the country) for many years doc have not had any computer “reminders” to screen for PCA, though there are reminders on dozens of other marginal issues — not in men with positive family histories, not in men with Agent Orange, not in men who are African American, not a reminder to any docs to consider a PSA, definitely not a reminder to do a DRE, not even to ask about urinary symptoms which many docs do not bother with unless the pt mentions them, but the doc is supposed to formally document asking about internet access and “food insecurity.” Patients have not even been offered a discussion about PCA screening and docs who did it were often chastised. Urologists ( many of them salaried moonlighting contractors with no academic affiliation) also fight not to do biopsies if at all possible, (more work) making many excuses for why a PSA velocity is up. To me, that is not “tip of the spear.” Maybe your VA area is different. I would take the fee for service guy any day, someone who does not answer as much to a government boss, and get multiple opinions. Having said that, if a proactive pt can push himself in with complaints of symptoms and dramatic PSA rise to get a biopsy, find PCA, and be referred to the local affiliate university hospital, he is in good shape to get good and appropriate prostate care, usually free or low cost, VA paying. Will see how long it takes for the new and improved 2018 “guidelines” for PCA screening to be incorporated into official health maintenance reminders for primary care.
Posts.Title: Interesting Article in Washington Post about PCA TReatment

Posts.Content: Dave, it sounds like you had good, objective care, which I know was at Hopkins. My post was just in response to your comment implying that being salaried creates objectivity in docs and is a good thing, which is also what one of the urologists in the article cited as an awesome thing, e.g., at VA. I was trying to bring up that docs being salaried, and/or working for government, e.g., creates different incentives that are not always beneficial to patients and can indeed be detrimental. They do not have to be detrimental anymore than fee for service incentives are, but often are, just in different ways (too little rather than too much, and/or with care issues applied to populations and not unique individuals, more one-size-fits-all). I hope you continue to receive appropriate and as best possible care.

He is getting general anesthesia, so he does not move, so NPO after midnight. 12 core on the usual template, and then three extra in the lesion. Oral antibiotic leviquin in the AM, and then ceftriaxone IV at procedure onset. His case is late in the afternoon. They say a week to get path but I have plans to try and get them sooner.

Posts.Content: 1. Short version: Prostate bx raises PSA, that is known, often a lot. In men without known PCA, does anyone have a good citation showing how long it takes for a PSA to return to pre-bx baseline after a bx, (an average time plus SD would be most useful) ? I have read anecdotes online about six weeks, twelve weeks, and six months. If no one has a citation, I am open to more anecdotes 2. Long version: I ask because DH, age 57, healthy, remains conflicted what to do. He has BPH and sxs he would like to be rid of, 50 gram prostate, but PSA bump from 1s over years to 4.2 and < 10% free, +FH PCA. His first and only bx 3/29/18 was an MRI guided fusion bx, standard template plus four cores in an area where he has a 2.6x1.4 cm Pirads4 peripheral lesion, at a large community hospital. Bxs all read as benign prostatic tissue with or without seminal vesicle tissue, confirmed path read at Hopkins, Epstein. There can be false postive Pirads 4 or even 5 images, but most of such lesions in the literature are smaller, or path shows the reasons for false positive ( prostatitis, granuloma, scar, etc.) so I have sent the images to UCSF radiology for a second read to see if they were overread, pending. If overread before, DH would feel a little more comfortable just rxing the BPH. DH has tentatively scheduled a GreenLight with loop procedure for mid July for his BPH but wonders if another PSA, say in June, would help him decide whether to go for another MRI biopsy first at another center, e.g., of PCA excellence. If PSA rising, then he would cancel the BPH procedure and go for another bx first. I am trying to find out if that would be too soon for the PSA to be interpretable if it is up from his 4.2 baseline. So far, I have not found a lot of information showing that first doing BPH surgery and later finding PCA and needing prostatectomy would create future problems. Both community urologists (trained at two different PCA centers of excellence 15-20 years ago) would either do BPH surgery if DH wants sxs controlled, or another PSA in six months, and explain away the Pirads4 with negative bx as sometimes that just happens. I read a paper from UT Dallas Djin cited from 2017 that showed 38% of pts whose first bx was an MRI guided bx of Pirads 5 lesions which were negative were then found to have significant PCA on subsequent either bx or prostatectomy, so these were false negative MRI guided bxs. There were some differences with DH other than the Pirads5: average age ten years older, average PSA 9 ( but wide variance), and though authors did not give ethnicity, likely a lot of African Americans, who have a higher bad PCA risk.

AgeInfo.Phrase: I ask because DH  age 57  healthy  remains conflicted what to

Posts.Content: I am in the San Francisco Bay area megalopolis, where multiple ACOs compete with each other to follow templated government approved protocols for patient care and where patients (unless they are rich and famous) are supposed to be happy to get what they get when they get it and not push or complain even if on private insurance. I will be proactive and aggressive getting the full biopsy report ASAP, and will make an appointment now. I have collected a list of nine highly regarded alternative surgeons but do not know about their office personnel. If by some miracle DH will not need PCA surgery, as he did not tolerate alpha blockers at all and has worsening prostatism symptoms, he would need prostate surgery anyway for that. I am glad I found this forum.
Posts.Title: Shortest and longest time people had to wait get biopsy results?

Posts.Content: Highlander, I agree with your last recommendation, but the rub is that this guy’s pts will never hear from him about the option of a PSA, so unless the pt is proactive on his own, he will not be presented with an option at all to get a hint he should change doctors. The government pays the bills (Medicare, Medicaid, VA, Tricare, Obamacare subsidies, even employer subsidized private insurance etc.) so they believe they can control the care patients get, or costs will spiral, so they feel entitled to becomes nannies. This doc apparently serves on a number of government advisory panels. HMOs people sign up for, either pre-Medicare or as part of Medicare Advantage, can also restrict PSA and bx access if there is a controversial area and just not pay for it, and people like Kenny have called for a ban on insurance coverage for the PSA draw and “unnecessary” (they decide) biopsies. Others in Accountable Care Organizations that have docs on salary have called for penalizing docs who order PSAs for screening. The same thing was done for mammograms in women 40-50 a few years ago, even though there are thousands of women < 50 diagnosed with breast cancer annually, many of whom die due to aggressive disease. I find it amazing Kenny did not even try and qualify his comment that “ideal PSA screening is no screeening” by excepting African-Americans and those with FH as high risk. His instructions not to screen also include no DRE, as that is a form of “screening”.
Posts.Title: Alternative to PSA?

Posts.Content: I posted separately, as a newbie spouse of my 57-year-old husband, that he is finally scheduled for MRI guided fusion bx with US 3/29 on his 2.6 cm x 1.4 in maximum length mass, despite size, oddly read as PiRADS 4. I want to line up a new expert urologist for detailed consultation, to see him just as soon as I will have bx results ( do not want the current guy to do the actual surgery, if that is needed, because of poor office communication and several hostile or confused personnel). I will be asking for genetic markers. What is your experience on how long you waited for bx results? Two days, a week, two weeks? Appointments with good people are hard to get in my urban area so I should probably not waste their time showing up without a biopsy report, but do not want much delay. Unfortunately the current urologist is n/a to communicate about this and his office manager clerk does not know or care to find out. Or should I just schedule now for next open even if the biopsy is not done or ready, because such a lesion is almost certainly going to be CA of one type or another? It only took two days for me to get my breast cancer biopsy report, and the next week I met with an off-plan surgeon, but easily available prostate CA docs who are good are harder to find short notice. Thanks in advance.

Appointments with good people are hard to get in my urban area so I should probably not waste their time showing up without a biopsy report, but do not want much delay. Unfortunately the current urologist is n/a to communicate about this and his office manager clerk does not know or care to find out. Or should I just schedule now for next open even if the biopsy is not done or ready, because such a lesion is almost certainly going to be CA of one type or another? It only took two days for me to get my breast cancer biopsy report, and the next week I met with an off-plan surgeon, but easily available prostate CA docs who are good are harder to find short notice. Thanks in advance.

Posts.Title: Shortest and longest time people had to wait get biopsy results?

Posts.Content: Highlander, one of the “political full moons” you refer to who wishes to go back to the good old days of non-screening for everyone is Kenny Lin. Recently Kenny Lin, M.D., MPH at Georgetown, said the following in an article/video published on-line on the medical discussion forum Medscape. " A New Prostate Cancer Screening Trial--Anything to See Here? - Medscape - Mar 16, 2018.” You have to register to have access to it and some people may not wish to do that, so here is the transcript (though those of you with significant disease found on screening may find it worth registering just to watch Dr. Lin’s self-confident face and manner as he continues to aggressively assert that the new recommendations moving towards at least considering a little more screening are wrong). He writes: “. . . .The recent publication of the third major randomized trial of prostate-specific antigen (PSA)-based screening for prostate cancer reported no difference in prostate cancer mortality after a median follow-up of 10 years in more than 400,000 men in primary care practices across the United Kingdom. Unlike the US Prostate, Lung, Colorectal, and Ovarian Cancer Screening (PLCO) trial, which also found no benefit, the UK trial evaluated a single invitation to PSA testing, rather than annual screening, and minimal testing occurred in the control group. My primary care colleagues and I are still waiting for the US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) to finalize its nearly year-old draft recommendation statement on prostate cancer screening, which I characterized in a Medscape commentary as a "surprising reversal." Rather than discouraging PSA screening for men of any age, the USPSTF instead advised that we routinely discuss the potential benefits and harms of screening in men aged 55-69 years and screen men who desire the test. I disagreed with this stance, which I think is analogous to advising clinicians to routinely discuss the potential benefits and harms of antibiotics for viral infections, or the potential benefits and harms of MRI in patients with uncomplicated acute low back pain. Others are contributing to the PSA debate in the pages of cancer journals, as a recent Medscape article reported. In a position statement published in the Journal of Clinical Oncology, a group of prominent urologists discussed the drop in PSA testing and prostate biopsy rates since 2012 and the rise in the percentage of men diagnosed with prostate cancer presenting with metastatic disease, which began around 2007 but now seems to be rising more sharply. They argued that in contrast to past years, when we were doing too much screening, too little screening is now being done, and they worry that a rise in morbidity and mortality from prostate cancer will follow. In order to get screening "just right," they propose two solutions: • For urologists, identifying and validating biomarkers to determine which patients with high PSA levels need prostate biopsy • For primary care physicians, "to engage in [more] conversations regarding screening that are individualized and centered on shared decision-making" I agree that the data show that primary care physicians are doing less PSA testing, but the metastatic prostate cancer statistic, derived from a study of the National Cancer Institute's SEER database, is misleading at best. We know that a substantial proportion of prostate cancers detected by PSA screening are overdiagnosed and would never become metastatic. Less PSA testing means that we are finding fewer of these cancers-in-name-only, so the proportion of all prostate cancers that are metastatic at diagnosis rises as a result. This is likely to be a statistical quirk rather than an early indication that less PSA testing will lead to more deaths. As for having family physicians do more shared decision-making with men about PSA testing, a commentary in JAMA Oncology by an internist and two oncologists argued that such discussions are a "mirage" in the real world of primary care. The authors asserted that in contrast to guideline recommendations, "the majority of decisions about PSA testing are not shared but made unilaterally by primary care physicians" due to multiple barriers, including time, competing demands, and a dearth of data on how race and family history affect one's risk for clinically important prostate cancer and the benefits and harms of screening. Further, they compared an elevated PSA level to "quicksand," where a cascade of invasive diagnostic interventions with scant supporting evidence can follow in rapid succession and create an unstoppable momentum of their own. Welcome to my world! Even though few family physicians are as familiar as I with the data and available resources for shared decision-making, most of my patients end up being totally perplexed and either defer the PSA screening decision to a spouse or significant other (who, naturally, wants them to be tested) or say, "Whatever you want to do is fine by me, doc." And in the precious time it takes for us to recognize this shared decision-making mirage, I may miss an opportunity to offer something else that clearly benefits my patient, such as colorectal cancer screening or tobacco-cessation counseling. This tradeoff is a potential harm of shared decision-making that neither the current USPSTF nor academic urologists fully recognize. It is the reason that I persist in telling colleagues and students that the amount of PSA screening that's "just right" should be a lot closer to none at all. This has been Dr Kenny Lin for Medscape Family Medicine. Thank you for listening.” I cannot include the comments, but they were as you would expect, especially from people with PCA. • 44 Read Comments References

Posts.Title: Alternative to PSA?

Posts.Content: Highlander, I agree with your last recommendation, but the rub is that this guy’s pts will never hear from him about the option of a PSA, so unless the pt is proactive on his own, he will not be presented with an option at all to get a hint he should change doctors. The government pays the bills (Medicare, Medicaid, VA, Tricare, Obamacare subsidies, even employer subsidized private insurance etc.) so they believe they can control the care patients get, or costs will spiral, so they feel entitled to becomes nannies. This doc apparently serves on a number of government advisory panels. HMOs people sign up for, either pre-Medicare or as part of Medicare Advantage, can also restrict PSA and bx access if there is a controversial area and just not pay for it, and people like Kenny have called for a ban on insurance coverage for the PSA draw and “unnecessary” (they decide) biopsies. Others in Accountable Care Organizations that have docs on salary have called for penalizing docs who order PSAs for screening. The same thing was done for mammograms in women 40-50 a few years ago, even though there are thousands of women < 50 diagnosed with breast cancer annually, many of whom die due to aggressive disease. I find it amazing Kenny did not even try and qualify his comment that “ideal PSA screening is no screeening” by excepting African-Americans and those with FH as high risk. His instructions not to screen also include no DRE, as that is a form of “screening”.

Posts.Title: Alternative to PSA?

Posts.Content: My DH at 57 is almost same age as yours. I sat with him at the initial urology appointment with his PSA of 4.2 and <10% free report from his primary care doc, and many years of worsening BPH symptoms he ignored. I asked the doc to comment on my reading that 30-50% of patients with free PSA this low have some level of cancer, and he just shrugged and replied that 50% or more do not and many of those have BPH. No citation offered, but it does make some sense. BTW meanwhile DH had his MRI I pushed for, and which insurance covered, and which showed a 2.5x1.4 cm suspicious area. The guided bx is 3/29. I hope it is just a big nest of prostatitis and a false positive, despite the free PSA being low, and also wish your DH a negative MRI on 4/1!
Posts.Title: BHP and age in improve odds?

Posts.Content: As you noted, Mama, your DH has higher PSA, so your doc may have combined that with his young age, and trend, to conclude what he did though everyone agrees bx is needed My DH has positive family history PCA in the dad, but that did not impress the blase GU. We will all know very soon one way or the other, unless false negative.
